p: Access to healthcare and life-saving antiretroviral therapy (ART) varies greatly across regions and depends on structural and individual factors [ 1– 3]. Access to HIV testing is a prerequisite to ART initiation, but delayed HIV diagnosis and linkage to care are major barriers to timely access to ART, and thus, its clinical benefits [ 3– 6]. Largely a consequence of increases in the uptake of universal HIV screening during pregnancy to prevent mother-to-child HIV transmission over the last decade, women from most geographical regions are diagnosed with HIV earlier and have higher CD4 + cell counts at diagnosis than heterosexually infected men [ 1, 3– 6]. These factors underlie some of the reported mortality differences between women and men favoring women [ 7– 11]. However, no study has so far specifically compared early and late mortality differences among women living with HIV (WLWH) across different geographical regions worldwide.
